Package hu.bme.mit.theta.core.type.bvtype

Bitvector type and its expressions. Use BvExprs to create them. Bitvectors can be used to simulate machine integers that can be signed/unsigned with a fixed range and wraparound overflow semantics. For example, 255+1 on 8 unsigned bits will result in 0. - BvType: the actual bitvector type - BvLitExpr: bitvector literal - BvConcatExpr: bitvector concatenation - BvExtractExpr: bitvector extraction - BvNegExpr: unary minus - BvPosExpr: unary plus - BvAddExpr: addition - BvSubExpr: subtraction - BvMulExpr: multiplication - BvUDivExpr: unsigned division - BvSDivExpr: signed division - BvSModExpr: modulus - BvURemExpr: unsigned remainder - BvSRemExpr: signed remainder - BvNotExpr: bitwise not - BvAndExpr: bitwise and - BvOrExpr: bitwise or - BvXorExpr: bitwise xor - BvShiftLeftExpr: shift left - BvArithShiftRightExpr: arithmetic shift right - BvLogicShiftRightExpr: logical shift right - BvRotateLeftExpr: rotate left - BvRotateRightExpr: rotate right - BvEqExpr: equal - BvNeqExpr: not equal - BvUGtExpr: unsigned greater - BvULtExpr: unsigned less - BvUGeqExpr: unsigned greater or equal - BvULeqExpr: unsigned less or equal - BvSGtExpr: signed greater - BvSLtExpr: signed less - BvSGeqExpr: signed greater or equal - BvSLeqExpr: signed less or equal
